newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singaporeans urged to show a little kindness.
newsitem.headline: Singaporeans urged to show a little kindness.

text.p: Singapore has started a movement to make random acts of kindness second nature to citizens of the bustling city-state, the Straits Times reported on Saturday.
The Small Kindness Movement aims to encourage Singaporeans to commit themselves to gracious living by performing daily acts of kindness, like giving up a parking spot to another driver.
The movement comes in response to Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong's appeal to Singaporeans to build a gracious society even as the country strives to maintain its competitive edge.
The newspaper quoted Noel Hon, chairman of the movement and of the Singapore Courtesy Council, as saying: "Being gracious and economically competitive are not mutually exclusive."
The "be kind" message will initially be targeted at students and later spread to government ministries, private companies and members of the public.
